intro: Taraxacum sect. taraxacum, commonly known as the dandelion, is a genus of flowering plants in the family Asteraceae. These plants are characterized by their basal rosettes of serrated, hairy leaves and their distinctive yellow composite flowers that develop into fluffy white seed heads. They are native to Europe, Asia, and North Africa but have been naturalized in many regions around the world. The species within this section are perennial herbs that typically grow in disturbed soils and open habitats. They are known for their ability to produce a large number of seeds, which are dispersed by wind, contributing to their widespread distribution.
